thread.title: Myer faces claims its cleaners are underpaid
thread.title_full: Myer faces claims its cleaners are underpaid

author: The Sydney Morning Herald
title: Myer faces claims its cleaners are underpaid
text:
The Myer store in Bourke Street, Melbourne Photo: Scott Barbour
Retail giant Myer has come under fire after cleaners working at its stores claimed they were being underpaid and denied entitlements.
The cleaners' union, United Voice, is concerned the workers are being exploited through an illegal practice known as sham contracting.
The retailer has tried to distance itself from the allegations and directed questions to its cleaning contractor, Spotless, which hires cleaning subcontractors.
But it is not the first time Myer has faced such claims. In July, its former cleaning subcontractor was forced to pay more than $6000 to underpaid cleaners working at Myer stores.
Advertisement Just three months later, a cleaner at a store in Melbourne has told the ABC's 7.30 program he is paid a flat rate of $20 per hour.
The minimum award rate for cleaners hired on a casual basis is $23 per hour, but they should also receive penalty rates or loading for working late hours, long hours or on weekends.
Cleaners working at Myer also told the ABC they had to pay their own insurance, tax and superannuation.
Sham contracting refers to when an employer disguises an employment relationship as an independent contracting arrangement to avoid paying employee entitlements.
The Fair Work Ombudsman has opened an investigation into alleged underpayments to workers at Myer's stores.
"The Fair Work Ombudsman has for some time held concerns about the workplace practices, including allegations of underpayment of workers, by cleaning contractors engaged by Myer at various sites," the Ombudsman said in statement to the ABC.
 In separate statements to the ABC, both Myer and Spotless said they would investigate the claims.
"Cleaners for Myer stores are provided by Spotless and we have sought a full and urgent explanation about the matter raised by the ABC," Myer's statement said.
